newsitem.title: CHINA: China '96 aluminium firms profits down 91.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: China '96 aluminium firms profits down 91.5 pct.

text.p: The post-tax profits of China's main aluminium plants were 5.99 million yuan ($72 million) in 1996, down 91.5 percent compared with 2.5 billion yuan in 1995, the China Economic Times said on Thursday.
"China's aluminium firms almost worked in vain in 1996," the newspaper quoted an official of the China National Nonferrous Metals Industry Corp as saying.

Output value of the aluminium plants directly under the China National Nonferrous Metals Industry Corp was 9.82 billion yuan, up 7.0 percent from 1995 while the pre-tax profits were 850 million yuan, down 63.1 percent, the official said.
The aluminium firms reported more than 600 million yuan of losses in the first two months of this year, he said.

In the first 10 months of 1996, total losses of China's 12 main aluminium plants hit 143 million yuan. Output of the 12 main firms account for about half of the national total, an earlier report said.
Steep falls in world prices were partly to blame for losses in China's aluminium industry, the newspaper said.
Domestic aluminium prices fell to 15,000 yuan per tonne from 18,000 yuan because of the impact of the international market, it said.
The newspaper also attributed the mounting losses to rising electricity prices, the burden of loan interest payments and poor management of enterprises.
China's aluminium firms paid more than 1.25 billion yuan in power fees last year, accounting for 38 percent of total production costs, it said.
Interest on bank loans paid by firms reached 3.65 million yuan in 1996, it said.
